review_title: A great company full of integrity and Work / Life balance
pros: When this company says integrity, they mean it - it's even on the seal of the rotunda at their beautiful corporate headquarters.  Work / Life balance is also key to keeping their employees happy as the company offers everyone an alternate work schedule where you can work 9 days x 9 hrs and get the 10th day off for free.  The people that I work with are great, friendly, and down to earth people and the management is making some great decisions in core areas (going from mostly Gas to Oil shale plays) while divesting assets that don't make sense (sold their Canadian assets and Midstream assets earlier this year).
cons: There are pockets of people that you have to know to get promoted, otherwise the company goes outside for people (they just hired their CFO from outside the company).  They need to execute better in the areas they acquired (aka GeoSouthern in Eagleford). They need to continue working on keeping their employees happy and over-communicate with their long term strategy.  Need to also find a place for employees that are still working in groups that have been divested.

pros: The Records Management department instilled a lot of trust and independence in the position over time. It began with thorough training/shadowing to become familiar with the ins and outs of oil and gas records management, and ultimately turned into allowing me to be very independent once they saw what kind of work I could produce. The pay was generous, and they allowed me to work part-time during the school year (in addition to full-time summers) while most interns only are allowed to work summers. They also always made it clear that school came before work, and I respected that very much because they were always understanding and flexible with my schedule. Lastly, I was never "pigeon-holed", I was exposed to various aspects within the department so it kept things interesting. I was also offered benefits after being there awhile, which was very nice for being an intern.
cons: Honestly, there weren't many major downsides that I can think of. The supervisors and employees within the department were all very nice and helpful. A significant downturn in the oil industry led to a round of layoffs, so unfortunately I was not able to secure employment in the long-term, but the company can not be blamed. It happened at a lot of firms, not just Devon. I wish management was a little more straight-forward about the layoff situation rather than keep things vague, but other than that it was a wonderful experience that I thoroughly enjoyed.

pros: When the company is doing well they take good care of their people. The benefits are great (private, on site medical clinic, insurance, cash bonus, alternate work schedule,  fitness center, severance package)
cons: When oil prices are down, they cut jobs by the hundreds to reduce overhead, starting with IT project staff. If you want relative stability as IT staff, get a position in one of the business units ASAP, but understand that any position can be at risk with this company.

pros:
-Bonus
-Ability to purchase vacation time
-Valuable work experience
-Good Values! Devon wants good people!
cons:
-9 hour work day (imposed 1 hour lunch break)
-Poor management in some main departments, no sense of open communication or leadership (you will seek them out, not the other way around)
-Sniper method of firing people
-Opportunity to advance if someone passes away, retires or is fired.
-10% opportunity to use your real skills and knowledge 
-lots of gossip (mainly due to the fact of poor leadership by management and leaders)

pros: 1) Work-life balance supported by generous time off package (4 weeks vacation + 12 flex days which are equal to vacation days + ability to purchase up to 2 additional weeks of vacation). 2) Ability to work in team setting with very talented and action oriented individuals. 3) High level of responsibility with oversight for robust capital budgets. 4) Top quartile compensation package (high base salary + 12% of base annual cash top-up into savings/pension plans + annual performance bonus + annual grant of DVN stock with vesting schedule)
cons: 1) SAP which although a very robust tool, is still not mature in the company and continues to undergo changes causing significant frustration from the "bottle neck" effect it creates. 2) Canadian division undergoing changes which sometimes leads to lack of clarity on the process/expectations.

job_title: IT Analyst in Oklahoma City, OK
pros: If the oil industry is booming then they want you to "give".
cons: They abuse and use the contracting industry to avoid paying any benefits of any kind. No holidays paid, no vacation paid, not sick days paid, no 50% off meals at the "restaurant", no gym usage, no being allowed to attend any functions they company provides and of course no retirement, no pension, no matching IRA contributions. And when they get rid of you they don't even tell you about it or give you any kind of notice to allow you to be looking for another position. Working at Devon is NOT a good thing unless you are one of the "chosen few" that are even full-time employees. Sure making a living off the backs of contractors gives Devon more money for the employees, but it is not ethical to do what they do. It is NOT a "top 100 place to work". Don't believe me? Then ask the 200+ people they fired from IT because management was incompetent. Then ask all the contractors that get screwed with NO PAID TIME OFF.

job_title: Eng Prod Tech in Oklahoma City, OK
pros: Great benefits, flexible work week, good compensation. Great people to work with!
cons: A shift in upper management has changed the culture at Devon and mass lay-offs due to downturn in O&G market don't help. Significant changes in data management structure and data analytic platforms make it very difficult for techs to perform their job because of inflexibility in the ability to manipulate data. Management has favorites and they want the good ole boy yes men. If you are out spoken, innovative beyond their vision, you will not do well here.

review_title: Extend benefits across the board. 9/80 for all locations.

cons:

review_title: Poor Leadership and Toxic Work Environment (Zero Rating)
pros: Some good managers and front-line workers that do care and value their work.  Sidenote: Most of those people are gone now from the organization becuase they did not "fit into" the organization.

pros: This is good company to work for. I worked there five and a half years. Like the other oil and gas companies, they provide good benefits for their employees. In addition, you'll find good people there to work with and work for.

This always effects jobs, but the company trys to take care of the employees that can not relocate.

review_title: Devon is not a good company to work for.
pros: I didn't experience much pros working at Devon.
cons:
The company I worked at was bought out by Devon and all the employees went to Devon.
From day one we observed Devon management talking with a forked tongue.
The atmosphere at Devon was very high stress and demanding. The management did a very good job at making the employees feel insignificant. 
When the oil market took a downturn, Devon management started firing people by fabricating stories that the employees were not performing up to standards. This way, Devon did not have to pay a package or honor the employees contract and retention bonus.
Management has IT monitoring employees internet activity.
Know employees that were counseled for going to the kitchen several times a day and refilling their coffee cup.
I could go on and on about questionable management tactics at Devon, but I think my point has been made.
Devon is by far the worst company I have ever worked for. 
Try your best to stay away from this company.

pros:
Great place to work if in the tower in OKC.

Compensation was good and the perks like the workout center and the cafeteria were good.

Until the industry downturn there were tons of training opportunities.
cons:
They played lip service to utilizing older, more experienced employees to bring along younger employees.  Yet when the layoffs hit it seems that a disproportionate number of people over 50 were let go, keeping younger clueless employees.  Everyone that I knew over 50 were terminated.

Layoffs were decided by HR with no input from supervisors or managers.  Therefore it seems that layoffs were not based on performance but only on salary.

As with almost any company in the oil & gas industry, when it's good, it's very good.  When it's bad, you're just a number.

pros: Great building, gym, restaurants, etc
cons: They pride themselves on transparency and ethics but their words and actions do not add up. One of their favorite things to tell recruits is that they do not have layoffs. In 2105, they had a town hall and several VP's met with groups to reassure them that they were not having layoffs and things would be fine. They started laying people off 2 weeks later. They call it job elimination and job restructuring to avoid bad press. Why not just be honest? Tell employees that while they will try to keep everyone, that with the current environment it may not be possible. I was glad to see that they finally did this in 2016 but I know that the way the cuts will be made will not be fair and will be political in nature, but at least they finally told the truth for once.

review_title: Very Political and Drama from Management/Supervisor level
job_title: Revenue Accountant in Oklahoma City, OK
pros:
Great benefits!

Competitive pay, parking garage, 401k matching, awesome vacation/holiday, alternative work schedule, gym on campus, car wash in parking garage, colleagues are great to work with.
cons:
Devons culture has TANKED since the layoff in 2015.

Management and supervisor level employees simply seem to not know how to make QUALITY decisions, unless quality means changing directions every three months. This leaves many guessing as to what the performance goals really are for the year. Many colleagues have experienced the same issue. 

Colleagues have expressed that they have been given a metric to meet at the beginning of the year. By the end of the year, Devon management has changed their direction, and that metric becomes obsolete and irrelevant to this new metric that takes priority because it is a fire and must be done NOW, NOW, NOW! Thus causing employees under the supervisor level trying to shift directions, therefore, not getting either metric completed fully during the year. At which point they usually get a sub par performance review because they weren't able to get their original metric completed. Had this been one person I wouldn't be leaving this as a con, but it happens to a lot of people here.

This scenario has happened to at least 6 different colleagues of mine over the past two years.

Management/supervisor levels also do NOT like you to offer a different solution to the problem. It is their way or the highway, there are no alternatives. They will say your opinion is welcomed and seem nice while you are providing it, but I have others reputation being thrashed behind closed doors for offering their opinion, even if it is a good solution to the problem. Seriously, if you work here in PRA, keep your head down for that...

review_title: Great work environment, competitive pay, great benefits
pros: There are many improvements to made in all aspects of the business. I find this enticing as an employer, as there are many projects underway and plenty of work to do. The people are very nice and very professional. The building is great and the offices are more than satisfactory. Accommodations such as the parking garage, dry cleaning, car wash, food court, and gym just add to the positive work environment. I don't know of many employers in Oklahoma that offer such accommodations.
cons: Promoting from within often times motivates individual contributors to work harder and learn new things. However, I have seen more leadership positions filled from outside than from within. pros: Gorgeous building, great lunch cafe/food, free parking

All of what is said about how this company treats contractors is true. Any issue I had with anything I was told by management to go to the contracting agency.  The department I was in was going to be restructured and I was left in a lurch. I was not trained properly and one of my co-workers was a constant gossip.  It seemed that many people in this particular department were also gossipers.  If you don't like to gossip, you don't fit in. Whenever I tried to go above and beyond to do my job even though I wasn't being trained properly I was told not to do it.  So, when I would back off I was told that I should be doing the thing they told me not to do.  Severely, and I mean severely, micromanaged.  It is ridiculous how micromanaged it is at Devon.   Also, if you aren't in the club you just don't fit in.  I felt like I stuck out in the office as much as the building sticks out on our skyline.  It was a very odd experience and quite a let down.  Managers need to lead, not just give out duties.  I should have known, though, because I wasn't even called in to a persona face-to-face interview with the manager of the department where I was working... And the pay for the work was also absolutely hideous.

pros: Well compensated salary and benefits package. Corporate wellness perks such as on-site fitness and cafeteria facilities. One of the more financially prudent O&G companies. Fairly decent internal corporate training options.

Awful management and leadership practises, very ineffective. Stuck in the 1950s for corporate culture. Poor engagement scores among employees despite advertising otherwise. The great places to work program masks the culture problems that will take you 6 months to discover. Highly toxic work environment, management regularly totes the "perception is everything" line, and bases decisions mostly on rumour and fear. Management decisions regularly compromise advertised corporate values. Highly political environment, very difficult to get anything done.

There's a large dictatorship faction in the company. Management functions with a strong preference for command & control, and doesn't heed advice from front-line employees. Devon hires a ton of former military members who are excellent in command & control but are often abrasive, brass, and have difficulty transitioning to civilian work-life. They struggle to work well with others, "HR moments" are quite frequent. As a result of all of this, working at Devon feels like being in the military where you're constantly bullied and forced to tow the corporate line or get out. There's a history of firing high-performing employees who've spoken out constructively on these issues. They're labeled as "not a good fit".

Cross-border management is a large challenge that most often results in ostracized team members. Management has a poor sense of people resource limitations and commits to several initiatives without considering if they have the capacity to actually fulfill them. Low chance of project success as a result. Most employees end up feeling suppressed and keep their mouths shut in order to keep collecting the high paycheque.
